column4: Soundray:  Firefox exhibits the same behaviour with the IP address - it says "waiting" forever.
Interestingly, I found another person with the same problem on a forum, and they reported that they could also connect to ibm.com.  I have just tried and indeed I am also able to connect to ibm.com.
Soundray:  The problem does not appear to be limited to firefox.  I am unable to use apt-get and unable to connect to IRC.
(I am IRCing from a laptop)
How are you connected to the internet? Are you behind a router?
Yes, I am behind a router, but I have also tried connecting directly to the cable modem, and I had the same results.
Hmm.. and firefox is not responding, but you can ping whatever site you want?
Just for a try. Why don't you set the MTU to 1492 for your network device?
How do I set the MTU for my network device?
first open a terminel and verify your device. ifconfig <--- post your device

I have run ifconfig.  Of course I am not IRCing from the same computer as the Ubuntu installation, and that computer (my main desktop) is unable to connect to IRC.  What would you like to know from my ifconfig?
And moreover, how do I change my MTU?
Clear ;) I am stupid... You can change your MTU with something like 'sudo ifconfig eth0 mtu 1942'
My goodness, that worked!  Thank you so much!  Can you explain to me what MTU is and why that was a problem?
It looks like your provider or your router is blocking some communication ports for data packages. Try to configure your router

What should I be looking to configure in my router?  Why would this issue not also affect my windows installation on the same machine?  Why does changing the MTU fix the problem?  Is there a disadvantage to leaving the MTU at 1492?

THe package size of your linux computer is sending '1500' size, where providers normally use 1942. That normally is not a problem because the network interfaces can split packages if they can negociate with eachother
I think I understand.  I am currently running Coova (based on OpenWRT) on my router.  Which setting should I be looking to change?
You have to open some communication ports, or tell the system to leave them open. There should be a preset for that kind of thing.
I have to google for the ports...

Which ports need to be opened?  I mean, I realize you don't know the numbers off hand, but what are the ports in question used for and how does the packet size relate to these ports?  Also, does windows use an MTU of 1492 and thus was unaffected by this problem?
Give me a second...
Well no problem, but if you don't configure your router, you will have to do the 'sudo-thing' each time you boot... ;(
